title: 999-B
statement: B. Reversing Encryptiontime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputA string $$$s$$$ of length $$$n$$$ can be encrypted by the following algorithm:iterate over all divisors of $$$n$$$ in decreasing order (i.e. from $$$n$$$ to $$$1$$$),for each divisor $$$d$$$, reverse the substring $$$s[1 \\dots d]$$$ (i.e. the substring which starts at position $$$1$$$ and ends at position $$$d$$$).For example, the above algorithm applied to the string $$$s$$$="codeforces" leads to the following changes: "codeforces" $$$\\to$$$ "secrofedoc" $$$\\to$$$ "orcesfedoc" $$$\\to$$$ "rocesfedoc" $$$\\to$$$ "rocesfedoc" (obviously, the last reverse operation doesn't change the string because $$$d=1$$$).You are given the encrypted string $$$t$$$. Your task is to decrypt this string, i.e., to find a string $$$s$$$ such that the above algorithm results in string $$$t$$$. It can be proven that this string $$$s$$$ always exists and is unique.InputThe first line of input consists of a single integer $$$n$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 100$$$) â€” the length of the string $$$t$$$. The second line of input consists of the string $$$t$$$. The length of $$$t$$$ is $$$n$$$, and it consists only of lowercase Latin letters.OutputPrint a string $$$s$$$ such that the above algorithm results in $$$t$$$.ExamplesInput10rocesfedocOutputcodeforcesInput16plmaetwoxesisihtOutputthisisexampletwoInput1zOutputzNoteThe first example is described in the problem statement.

processed.result:
You are given a string $t$ of length $n$.  This string was created by applying the following algorithm to a string $s$:

1. Find all the divisors of $n$ in descending order (from $n$ down to 1).
2. For each divisor $d$, reverse the substring of $s$ from the beginning to position $d$.

Your task is to find the original string $s$. 

**Example:**

If $t = "rocesfedoc"$ and $n = 10$, then the original string $s$ is "codeforces".
You are given a string that was created by repeatedly reversing parts of another string.  Your task is to find the original string.
